title: 108_hr1538
content: The "True American Heroes Act of 2003" is also known as the Act. It includes provisions for awarding Congressional Gold Medals to government workers who responded to the attacks on the World Trade Center and perished. The "True American Heroes Act of 2003" authorizes the presentation of gold medals to officers, emergency workers, and government employees who responded to the 9/11 attacks on the World Trade Center, to be given to their next of kin or personal representatives. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike gold medals with emblems symbolizing valor for 9/11 responders. Recipients will be determined after consulting with relevant authorities. Duplicates of the medals will be made for display in various offices and stations. The Governor of New York, Mayor of New York City, and other officials will have their portraits displayed in respective offices. Precinct houses, fire stations, and other duty stations will also display memorials for individuals assigned there on September 11, 2001. The Secretary may authorize the sale of duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price to cover costs. Congress recommends striking the medals at the US Mint in West Point, NY. Congress recommends striking Congressional Gold Medals at the US Mint in West Point, NY, including medals for individuals aboard United Airlines Flight 93 who resisted hijackers and caused the plane to crash. On September 11, 2001, United Airlines Flight 93 was hijacked by terrorists and crashed near Shanksville, Pennsylvania after passengers resisted the hijackers. United Airlines Flight 93 crashed prematurely, potentially saving lives and preventing the destruction of important symbols of democracy. The leaders of the resistance showed exceptional bravery and patriotism, deserving Congressional Gold Medals for their heroic service. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike gold medals for individuals who aided in resisting hijackers on United Airlines Flight 93. Duplicate bronze medals may also be sold to cover costs. Congressional Gold Medals will be awarded to government workers who responded to the Pentagon attacks and perished. Gold medals will be presented to officers, emergency workers, and employees of the US Government who responded to the Pentagon attacks on September 11, 2001. The design of the medals will be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine the number of medals and recipients after consulting with relevant officials. National medals struck under this title are considered national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. The Congress acknowledges the tragic events of September 11, 2001, where over 6,000 lives were lost in terrorist attacks in New York City, at the Pentagon, and in Pennsylvania. Emergency personnel responded heroically, and the nation united in support of the victims and their families. The civilized world stands against such cowardly acts of terrorism. The Congress acknowledges the tragic events of September 11, 2001, where over 6,000 lives were lost in terrorist attacks in New York City, at the Pentagon, and in Pennsylvania. Emergency personnel responded heroically, and the nation united in support of the victims and their families. The minting of coins in commemoration of the Spirit of America will pay tribute to the countless heroes who risked their lives during the attacks and in their aftermath, and to a united people whose belief in freedom, justice, and democracy has never wavered. SEC. 202. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins weighing 1 ounce with 91.67% gold, $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams with 90% silver, and half dollar clad coins. The Secretary will mint half dollar clad coins weighing 11.34 grams with a diameter of 1.205 inches. The number of gold coins minted shall be 25,000 plus a determined amount by the Secretary in consultation with the Attorney General and Governors of New York, Pennsylvania, and Virginia. The Secretary will mint $50 coins equal to the number of innocent individuals killed in the 9/11 attacks. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Only metals from natural deposits in the US or its territories can be used for minting. The Congress acknowledges the effectiveness of limitations on commemorative coins to stabilize markets and maximize demand. The events of September 11, 2001, sparked public interest in commemorative programs. The Congress acknowledges the importance of exempting coins produced for the Spirit of America fundraising program from limitations on commemorative coins, in response to the events of September 11, 2001. The design of coins minted under this title shall commemorate the tragic events of September 11, 2001, with specific inscriptions and symbols. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by a citizens advisory committee. SEC. 204. STRIKING AND ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this title shall generally be issued in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins which shall be issued only in proof quality. Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike a particular quality of coins, except for half dollar coins which can be struck at any number of facilities. The Secretary must start issuing coins promptly after the enactment of this Act and must cease issuance after one year. Coins minted under this title must be issued promptly after enactment and must cease issuance after one year. Coins minted under this title must be issued promptly after enactment and must cease issuance after one year. The sale of coins is regulated under Section 205. The Secretary sells coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Bulk sales are discounted, and prepaid orders receive a reasonable discount. Gold coins are exempt from certain regulations. The Secretary sells coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs, with bulk sales discounted and prepaid orders receiving a reasonable discount. Additionally, the Secretary shall issue a 50 dollar gold coin for presentation to the next of kin or personal representative of individuals identified under a specific section, with arrangements made by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate. SEC. 206. Surcharges on sale of coins. The Secretary will add a surcharge to coin sales to cover production costs, with specific amounts for different denominations. Any excess proceeds will be used to cover production costs of all coins issued under this title. The surcharge on coin sales will cover production costs for gold medals not recovered from bronze medal sales. Any remaining funds will be transferred to a fund for victims of the September 11, 2001 tragedies. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 11, 2003.
